Any factor that interferes with either formation or removal of amniotic fluid may therefore result in a rapid change in amniotic fluid volume.</p>
<p>Congenital abnormalities that are associated with impaired ability to ingest amniotic fluid are commonly associated with excessive amniotic fluid volume, a condition known as polyhydramnios.</p>
<p>In summary, amniotic fluid is formed by the secretion and transudation of fluid through the amnion and fetal skin and from the passage of fetal urine into the amniotic sac. Circulation of amniotic fluid occurs by reabsorption of fluid through the fetal gut, skin and amnion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="volume">Volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By 8 weeks gestation, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5-10 \mathrm{~mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> of amniotic fluid has accumulated. Thereafter, the volume increases rapidly in parallel with fetal growth and gestational age up to a maximum volume of 1000 mL at 38 weeks. Subsequently, the volume diminishes so that by 42 weeks, it may fall below 300 mL . The estimation of amniotic fluid volume forms a standard part of the ultrasound assessment of fetal wellbeing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-significance-of-amniotic-fluid-volume">Clinical significance of amniotic fluid volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-significance-of-amniotic-fluid-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oligohydramnios">Oligohydramnios<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oligohydramnios" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The diminution of amniotic fluid volume is most commonly associated with impaired secretion of fluid and therefore is a sign of the impairment of placental function, with the exception of the effect of post-maturity. It may be associated with the preterm rupture of the membranes with chronic loss of amniotic fluid.</p>
<p>Oligohydramnios is commonly associated with intrauterine fetal growth restriction and is therefore an important sign of fetal jeopardy.</p>
<p>It is also associated with congenital abnormalities such as renal agenesis where there is no production of fetal urine.</p>
<p>Oligohydramnios is associated with various structural and functional problems in the fetus. It may be associated with pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory difficulties at birth. It may also cause physical deformities such as club foot, skull deformities and wry neck. In labour it has been associated with abnormal cord compression during contractions and hence with fetal hypoxia. Amniotic fluid infusions are used in some units to try and avoid these problems but the efficacy of these techniques remains in doubt.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="polyhydramnios">Polyhydramnios<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#polyhydramnios" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The presence of excessive fluid commonly arises as a chronic condition but may on occasions be acute.</p>
<p>Acute polyhydramnios is a rare condition that tends to arise in the second trimester or the early part of the third trimester and commonly results in the onset of preterm labour. The condition is painful for the mother and may cause dyspnoea and vomiting. The uterus becomes acutely distended and it may be necessary to relieve the pressure by amniocentesis. However, this only gives short-term relief and nearly always requires repeated procedures. There is often an underlying congenital abnormality. A rare cause is congenital diabetes insipidus. It could also be managed medically with indomethacin to the mother at a dose of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1-3 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{kg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span></span></span></span></span> body weight. Indomethacin over a prolonged period may cause renal and pulmonary arterial vasoconstriction and hence should be a thin space used only for a few days.</p>
<p>Chronic hydramnios may arise in those pregnancies where there is a large placenta, such as occurs in multiple pregnancy, chorioangioma of the placenta or a mother with diabetes. It may also be idiopathic, with no obvious underlying cause, and the fetus may be entirely normal. However, in approximately <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">30%</span></span></span></span></span> of all cases, there is a significant congenital anomaly. The distribution of such anomalies is as follows in order of frequency:</p>
<ul>
<li>anencephaly</li>
<li>oesophageal atresia</li>
<li>duodenal atresia</li>
<li>iniencephaly</li>
<li>hydrocephaly</li>
<li>diaphragmatic hernia</li>
<li>chorioangioma of the placenta.</li>
</ul>
<p>Hydramnios itself is associated with certain complications and these include:</p>
<ul>
<li>unstable lie</li>
<li>cord prolapse or limb prolapse</li>
<li>placental abruption if there is sudden release of amniotic fluid</li>
<li>postpartum haemorrhage associated with over distension of the uterus</li>
<li>maternal discomfort and dyspnoea.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-value-of-tests-on-amniotic-fluid">Clinical value of tests on amniotic fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-value-of-tests-on-amniotic-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Both the biochemical and cytological components of amniotic fluid can be used for a variety of clinical tests. However, many of the tests previously used have been replaced by ultrasonography and procedures such as cordocentesis and chorionic villus biopsy.</p>
<p>Amniotic fluid contains two distinct types of cell. The first group is derived from the fetus and the second from the amnion. Cells of fetal origin are larger and more likely to be anucleate, whereas those derived from the amnion are smaller, with a prominent nucleolus contained within the vesicular nucleus, and are found in proportionately greater numbers prior to the 32nd week of gestation.</p>
<p>Cells that stain with eosin are most prominent in early gestation and are derived from the amnion. After 38 weeks gestation, numbers of these cells fall to less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">30%</span></span></span></span></span> of the total cell population.</p>
<p>Basophilic cells increase in number as pregnancy progresses but also tend to decrease after 38 weeks. The presence of large numbers of these cells has been related to the presence of a female fetus; the fetal vagina is thought to be the possible source.</p>
<p>After 38 weeks, a large number of eosinophilic anucleate cells appear. These cells stain orange with Nile blue sulphate and are thought to be derived from maturing sebaceous cells.</p>
<p>These cells have been used in the past as a method of assessing gestational age but this has now been replaced as a method by ultrasound imaging and the assessment of fetal growth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amniocentesis">AMNIOCENTESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amniocentesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amniotic fluid is obtained by the procedure of amniocentesis. This procedure involves inserting a fine-gauge needle under aseptic conditions through the anterior abdominal</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5e785977.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 4.15 Amniotic fluid is obtained by the procedure of amniocentesis by inserting a needle into the amniotic sac under ultrasound guidance, avoiding the placenta where possible.
wall of the mother under local anaesthesia. The procedure, when used for diagnostic testing for chromosomal abnormalities, is commonly performed at 14-16 weeks gestation but can be performed as early as 12 weeks in some circumstances. The procedure must be performed under ultrasound control in order to identify the best and most accessible pool of amniotic fluid and, where possible, to avoid the placenta and the fetus. Up to 10 mL of fluid is withdrawn and the presence of a fetal heart beat is checked both before and after the procedure (Fig. 4.15).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indications-for-amniocentesis">Indications for amniocentesis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indications-for-amniocentesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chromosomal-abnormalities-and-sex-linked-diseases">Chromosomal abnormalities and sex-linked diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chromosomal-abnormalities-and-sex-linked-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The fetal karyotype can be determined by the culture of fetal cells obtained from amniotic fluid. This can reveal chromosome abnormalities such as those found in Down's syndrome, Turner's syndrome and various mosaics. It also allows the determination of fetal sex and hence may be useful in the management of sex-linked disorders such as thalassaemia, haemophilia and Duchenne's muscular dystrophy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolic-disorders">Metabolic disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are a number of rare metabolic disorders, such as Tay-Sachs disease and galactosaemia, that can be diagnosed using fetal cells obtained from amniotic fluid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="estimation-of-fetal-lung-maturity">Estimation of fetal lung maturity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estimation-of-fetal-lung-maturity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The estimation of lecithin or the lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio in amniotic fluid has been used to measure functional lung maturity in the fetus after 28 weeks gestation and prior to premature delivery, and where there is a significant risk of the child developing the respiratory distress syndrome. However, it is now routine practice to give the mother corticosteroids under these circumstances. Such is the efficacy of this procedure that it has reduced the need to use the test. Other tests for fetal maturity based on amniotic fluid have now been abandoned in favour of ultrasound techniques.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="essential-information">Essential information<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#essential-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="early-placental-development">Early placental development<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#early-placental-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Implantation of the blastocyst occurs by day 7</li>
<li>Formation of placental villi takes place from Langhans cells</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="further-placental-development">Further placental development<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#further-placental-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Maternal cotyledons form by 6 weeks after ovulation</li>
<li>Stem villi remain the functional unit of the placenta</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="umbilical-cord-structure">Umbilical cord structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#umbilical-cord-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Contains two arteries and a vein surrounded by Wharton's jelly and covered in epithelium</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="uteroplacental-blood-flow">Uteroplacental blood flow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uteroplacental-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Mean pressure 10 mmHg and flow at term <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>500</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>750</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">500-750 \mathrm{~mL} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">750</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> min</li>
<li>Can be impaired by haemorrhage, uterine contractions, adrenaline/noradrenaline</li>
<li>Impairment leads to fetal growth restriction and possible asphyxia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="placental-transfer-and-function">Placental transfer and function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#placental-transfer-and-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Gaseous exchange comes about by simple diffusion</li>
<li>Oxygen rapidly taken up by the fetal circulation even at low pressure</li>
<li>Fetal nutrition/excretion</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endocrine-function">Endocrine function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocrine-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>hCG - reaches peak between 10 and 12 weeks gestation</li>
<li>hPL</li>
<li>Progesterone - placenta produces about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>350</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">350 \mathrm{mg} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">350</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> day at term</li>
<li>Oestrogens - placenta major source, 20 different hormones</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fetal-development">Fetal development<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fetal-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Rate of fetal growth increases after 10 weeks and diminishes again towards term</li>
<li>Heartbeat present at 4-5 weeks</li>
<li>Cardiac output at term <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>200</mn><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">200 \mathrm{~mL}^{-1} \mathrm{~min}^{-1} \mathrm{~kg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0818em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8873em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">min</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8719em;"><span style="top: -3.1208em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span></span></span></span></span>, entirely dependent on heart rate</li>
<li>Regular respiratory pattern by mid-trimester</li>
<li>40-60 movements/min at 34 weeks</li>
<li>Principal surfactants sphingomyelin and lecithin</li>
<li>Production of lecithin reaches functional levels by 32 weeks</li>
<li>Surfactant production may be delayed by maternal diabetes</li>
<li>Most digestive enzymes present by 26 weeks</li>
<li>Fetal kidney completely formed by 36 weeks but most excretory functions performed by the placenta</li>
<li>Perception of sound begins between 16 and 24 weeks</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amniotic-fluid">Amniotic fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amniotic-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Fetal urine major contributor</li>
<li>Total volume turned over every 2-3 hours</li>
<li>Oligohydramnios</li>
<li>Associated with intrauterine growth restriction and congenital abnormalities, e.g. renal agenesis</li>
<li>May cause pulmonary hypoplasia, club foot, skull deformity, wry neck and fetal hypoxia in labour</li>
<li>Polyhydramnios</li>
<li>May be associated with multiple pregnancy, diabetes or congenital abnormality</li>
<li>May cause unstable lie, cord prolapse, placental abruption, postpartum haemorrhage</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-tests">Clinical tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Amniocentesis may help to detect chromosome abnormalities</li>
<li>Amniocentesis also detects fetal sex</li>
<li>Can be used to estimate fetal lung maturity where premature delivery is likely</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">Chapter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="perinatal-and-maternal-mortality">Perinatal and maternal mortality<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#perinatal-and-maternal-mortality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Boon H. Lim</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="learning-outcomes">Learning outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#learning-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After studying this chapter you should be able to:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="knowledge-criteria">Knowledge criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#knowledge-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Define maternal and perinatal mortality</li>
<li>List the main causes of maternal and perinatal mortality</li>
<li>Describe the socioeconomic factors that affect perinatal and maternal mortality</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-competencies">Clinical competencies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-competencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Interpret maternal and perinatal data</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="professional-skills-and-attitudes">Professional skills and attitudes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#professional-skills-and-attitudes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Reflect on the differences in the direct and indirect causes and the sociodemographic factors that influence these in different countries and cultures</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="perinatal-mortality">PERINATAL MORTALITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#perinatal-mortality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perinatal mortality is an important indicator of maternal care, health and nutrition; it also reflects the quality of obstetric and paediatric care. The understanding of perinatal mortality statistics is vital in enabling the development of a high quality approach to the surveillance of the causes of deaths, allowing health care systems to develop prevention strategies and to help clinicians and parents to understand the cause of deaths of their infants and to plan effective monitoring strategies for future pregnancies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="definitions">Definitions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definitions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The World Health Organization (WHO), in recognizing the importance of international comparison of perinatal and neonatal mortality, coordinates the compilation of health statistics and encourages member countries to rely on the same definitions when comparing the statistics. However, there remain slight differences in the definitions of perinatal mortality between some countries, reflecting the definition of viability and resources in the individual countries.</p>
<p>The definitions are drawn from the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mtext>th&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{\text {th }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> edition of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10). The key definitions are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Live birth: complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, irrespective of the duration of the pregnancy, which, after such separation, breathes or shows any other evidence of life, such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movement of voluntary muscles, whether or not the umbilical cord has been cut or the placenta is attached; each product of such a birth is considered live born.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stillbirth or fetal death: death prior to the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception, irrespective of the duration of pregnancy; the death is indicated by the fact that after such separation the fetus does not breathe or show any other evidence of life, such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord or definite movement of voluntary muscles.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Perinatal period: commences at 22 completed weeks (154 days) of gestation and ends seven completed days after birth.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neonatal period: begins with birth and ends 28 complete days after birth. Neonatal deaths may be subdivided into early neonatal deaths, occurring during the first seven days of life ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0-6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span></span></span></span></span> days), and late neonatal deaths, occurring after the seventh day but before the 28th day of life ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>27</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7-27</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">27</span></span></span></span></span> days).
In the UK the definitions are different, reflecting the survival rates and concept of viability. The present legal definitions that apply to England and Wales are as follows:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stillbirth: A baby delivered without signs of life after <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>23</mn><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">23^{+6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">3</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> weeks of pregnancy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Neonatal death: death of a liveborn infant occurring within 28 days of birth; an early neonatal death is defined as death during the first week of life ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0-6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span></span></span></span></span> completed days inclusive).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Perinatal death: death of a fetus or a newborn in the perinatal period that commences at 24 completed weeks gestation and ends before 7 completed days after birth.
In Australia and New Zealand, stillbirth is defined as 'Death prior to the complete expulsion or extraction from its mother of a product of conception of 20 or more completed weeks of gestation or of 400 g or more birth weight where gestation is not known. The death is indicated by the fact that after such separation the fetus does not breathe or show any other evidence of life, such as beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movement of voluntary muscles'.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mortality-rates">Mortality rates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mortality-rates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The current definitions are as follows:</p>
<ul>
<li>Perinatal mortality rate (PNMR): the number of stillbirths and early neonatal deaths (those occurring in the first week of life) per 1000 total births (live births and stillbirths)</li>
<li>Stillbirth rate (SBR): the number of stillbirths per 1000 total births</li>
<li>Neonatal mortality rate (NMR): the number of neonatal deaths occurring within the first 28 days of life per 1000 live births.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="incidence">Incidence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#incidence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perinatal mortality rates vary widely: both between different countries and within different regions of the same country. In spite of initiatives in many countries to improve maternal and child health, there remains a significant disparity between developed countries and the developing countries.</p>
<p>WHO publishes global estimates on perinatal mortality rates by level of development and geographical regions. For comparison, the regions are divided into the 'More developed, Less developed and Least developed' with figures demonstrating a stark contrast between the regions (Table 5.1). In countries where no data collection takes place, models are produced to estimate mortality based on demographic and health surveys conducted by several agencies. Worldwide, there are over 6.3 million perinatal deaths annually, almost all of which occur in developing countries, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>27</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">27 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">27%</span></span></span></span></span> occurring in the least developed countries alone, i.e. the sub-Saharan regions of central Africa. In developing countries, the PNMR is five times greater than in developed countries; in the least developed countries it is six time higher. It is highest in Africa, with 62 deaths per 1000 births, especially in middle and western Africa, with rates as high as 76 per 1000 births. The perinatal mortality rate in Asia is 50 per 1000 total births, with a peak of 65 per 1000 in South-central Asia.</p>
<p>Developed countries (Western Europe, North America, Japan, Australia and New Zealand) have seen a steady fall in the PNMR over the last 30 years. In the UK, the Centre for Maternal and Child Enquiries (CMACE) publishes annual perinatal reports and showed a statistically significant downward trend in the perinatal mortality rate, from 8.3 in 2000 to 7.5 per 1000 total births in 2008. This is due to both a statistically significant decrease in the early neonatal mortality rate (from 2.9 in 2000 to 2.5 in 2008</p>
<p>Table 5.1 Global comparison of perinatal and neonatal mortality rates by WHO regions in 2000</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Region</th><th style="text-align: center;">Perinatal mortality &lt;br&gt; rate (per 1000 births)</th><th style="text-align: center;">Stillbirth rate &lt;br&gt; (per 1000 births)</th><th style="text-align: center;">Early neonatal &lt;br&gt; rate (per 1000 &lt;br&gt; live births)</th><th style="text-align: center;">Neonatal mortality &lt;br&gt; rate (per 1000 live &lt;br&gt; births)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">More developed</td><td style="text-align: center;">10</td><td style="text-align: center;">6</td><td style="text-align: center;">4</td><td style="text-align: center;">5</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Less Developed</td><td style="text-align: center;">50</td><td style="text-align: center;">26</td><td style="text-align: center;">25</td><td style="text-align: center;">33</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Least Developed</td><td style="text-align: center;">61</td><td style="text-align: center;">31</td><td style="text-align: center;">31</td><td style="text-align: center;">42</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">World</td><td style="text-align: center;">47</td><td style="text-align: center;">24</td><td style="text-align: center;">23</td><td style="text-align: center;">41</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(Source: World Health Organization (2006) Neonatal and Perinatal Mortality: Country, Regional and Global Estimates. WHO Press, Geneva.)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1445838f.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 5.1 Stillbirth, neonatal and perinatal mortality rates for the UK, 2000-2008.
per 1000 live births) and a statistically significant decrease in the stillbirth rate (from 5.4 to 5.1 per 1000 live births, respectively) (Fig. 5.1).</p>
<p>The reasons for this improvement include:</p>
<ul>
<li>improved quality of obstetric and neonatal care</li>
<li>improved socioeconomic conditions</li>
<li>an active screening programme for common congenital abnormalities.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sociodemographic-factors-and-perinatal-mortality">Sociodemographic factors and perinatal mortality<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sociodemographic-factors-and-perinatal-mortality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Factors that are known to affect perinatal mortality in the UK and Australia include the sociodemographic characteristics of the mother such as maternal age, deprivation, ethnicity (Table 5.2). Smoking also has a significant adverse effect on birth weight and perinatal mortality.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="maternal-age">Maternal age<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#maternal-age" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Maternal age at both extremes is associated with an increase in perinatal mortality. Mothers under the age of 20 years were 1.3 times and older mothers ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;40</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span></span></span></span></span> years) 1.8 times more likely to have a stillbirth or neonatal death than mothers aged <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>29</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25-29</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">29</span></span></span></span></span> years of age.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deprivation">Deprivation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deprivation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The socioeconomic status of the mothers also has a statistically significant effect on the perinatal mortality rates in England. Mothers in the most deprived areas were 1.7 times more likely to have a stillbirth and 2.1 times more likely to have a neonatal death compared with mothers in the least deprived areas.</p>
<p>Table 5.2 Sociodemographic characteristics of mothers: England, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Crown Dependencies, 2008</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;">Stillbirth &lt;br&gt; rate (per &lt;br&gt; 1000 births)</th><th style="text-align: left;">Neonatal death &lt;br&gt; rate (per 1000 &lt;br&gt; live births)</th></tr></thead></table>
<p>Maternal age</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;20</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span></span></span></span></span></th><th style="text-align: left;">5.6</th><th style="text-align: left;">3.7</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20-24</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">24</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;">5.2</td><td style="text-align: left;">3.3</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>29</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25-29</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">29</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;">4.4</td><td style="text-align: left;">2.9</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>34</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30-34</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">34</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;">4.6</td><td style="text-align: left;">2.6</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>35</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>39</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35-39</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">39</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;">5.3</td><td style="text-align: left;">2.6</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mord">+</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;">7.8</td><td style="text-align: left;">2.9</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Deprivation (England)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">1 (Least deprived)</th><th style="text-align: left;">3.9</th><th style="text-align: left;">1.9</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">2</td><td style="text-align: left;">3.9</td><td style="text-align: left;">2.4</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">3</td><td style="text-align: left;">4.7</td><td style="text-align: left;">2.5</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">4</td><td style="text-align: left;">5.3</td><td style="text-align: left;">3.1</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">5 (most deprived)</td><td style="text-align: left;">6.5</td><td style="text-align: left;">4.0</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Ethnicity (England)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">White</th><th style="text-align: left;">4.2</th><th style="text-align: left;">2.4</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Black</td><td style="text-align: left;">9.9</td><td style="text-align: left;">5.7</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Asian</td><td style="text-align: left;">7.4</td><td style="text-align: left;">4.1</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Chinese</td><td style="text-align: left;">4.3</td><td style="text-align: left;">1.4</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Mixed</td><td style="text-align: left;">5.4</td><td style="text-align: left;">3.7</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Others</td><td style="text-align: left;">5.9</td><td style="text-align: left;">2.0</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(Source: Centre for Maternal and Child Enquiries (CMACE) (2010) Perinatal Mortality 2008 United Kingdom. CMACE, London.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ethnicity">Ethnicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ethnicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A statistically significant ethnic distribution compared to the general maternity population in the rates of stillbirths and neonatal mortality, with mothers of black and Asian ethnic origins being at highest risks was noted. Ethnic differences may be linked to employment and deprivation status. In Australia perinatal mortality rates are 30% higher in the indigenous population than in the population as a whole.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-maternal-characteristics">Other maternal characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-maternal-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The report showed that <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>22</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">22 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">22%</span></span></span></span></span> of mothers who had stillbirths and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>23</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">23 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">23%</span></span></span></span></span> of mothers whose babies died in the</p>
<p>neonatal period smoked during pregnancy, compared with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of women in the general population in England. Obesity was also a factor. In 2008, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>24.9</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">24.9 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">24.9%</span></span></span></span></span> of the general population of women in England were recorded to be obese (BMI <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;30</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span></span></span></span></span> ). The report showed that <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>24</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">24 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">24%</span></span></span></span></span> of mothers who had stillbirths and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>23</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">23 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">23%</span></span></span></span></span> of mothers who had neonatal deaths fell into the obese group. There was no statistical difference in outcomes when parity, early booking, presentation at birth or mode of delivery were compared. Past obstetric history such as preterm birth, mid-trimester loss, recurrent miscarriage and pre-eclampsia were important factors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-stillbirths">Causes of stillbirths<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-stillbirths" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Stillbirths are the largest contributor to perinatal mortality. It is important to classify the causes of stillbirths in order to help with the understanding of the antecedents. The traditionally used systems such as the Wigglesworth and the Aberdeen (Obstetric) classifications consistently reported up to two-thirds of stillbirths as being from unexplained causes. Many newer classifications have been developed that have resulted in a significant reduction of the numbers of stillbirths being classified as unexplained. One such system, the ReCoDe (Relevant Condition at Death) system, which classifies the relevant condition present at the time of death, was developed by the Perinatal Institute, Birmingham, UK. By using this system, the Perinatal Institute identified that the most common cause of stillbirth was fetal growth restriction (43%) and only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15.2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15.2 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15.2%</span></span></span></span></span> remained unexplained. More than one condition can be classified so that both a primary and secondary code can be assigned.</p>
<p>Recognizing the importance of understanding the causes of stillbirths better, CMACE came up with a new classification in the 2008 Perinatal Mortality report that had an increased focus on placental pathology in attempting to recognize patterns in causes of death or identifying preventable causes. As a result of this new classification, 23% of stillbirths were unexplained. The main causes identified in the CMACE classification were (Fig. 5.2):</p>
<ul>
<li>antepartum or intrapartum haemorrhage</li>
<li>intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)</li>
<li>specific placental conditions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intrapartum-stillbirth">Intrapartum stillbirth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intrapartum-stillbirth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The WHO estimations have shown that intrapartum stillbirths are rare in developed countries, representing approximately <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>8.8</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">8.8 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">8.8%</span></span></span></span></span> in the UK) of the estimated 84000 stillbirths, with an average intrapartum stillbirth rate of 0.6 per 1000 births. By contrast, intrapartum stillbirths in developing regions were estimated to be between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>24</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">24 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">24%</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>37</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">37%</span></span></span></span></span> of all stillbirths, with an average rate of 9 per 1000 births occurring during delivery.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-26c39767.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 5.2 Causes of stillbirth in 2008 using the new CMACE classification for England, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Crown Dependencies. IUGR, intrauterine growth restriction.</p>
<p>Complications of childbirth are the cause of almost all the intrapartum deaths; these are largely avoidable through the provision of appropriately trained birth attendants and facilities. Whilst most deliveries in developed countries take place in institutions and in the presence of qualified health personnels, only just over <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> of deliveries occur in health facilities in developing countries. Only slightly more than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of births take place with the assistance of a qualified health professional.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-neonatal-deaths">Causes of neonatal deaths<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-neonatal-deaths" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The global picture shows that congenital anomalies and prematurity, birth trauma and infections remain significant causes of neonatal deaths. Early neonatal deaths are mostly due to complications during pregnancy or childbirth, preterm birth and malformations; late neonatal deaths are due to neonatal tetanus and infections acquired either at home or in hospital.</p>
<p>Low birth weight, although not a direct cause of neonatal death, is an important association. Around <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of newborn infants weigh less than 2500 g , ranging from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">6%</span></span></span></span></span> in developed countries to more than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">30%</span></span></span></span></span> in the poorly developed countries. Birth weight is undoubtedly an indication of maternal health and nutrition. Neonatal tetanus remains a common cause of neonatal death in settings where lack of hygiene and inadequate cord care are prevalent, as many women are not immunized against tetanus. The majority of deaths from neonatal tetanus occur between the 7th and 10th day of life.</p>
<p>In the UK, the neonatal classification used by CMACE looked at the primary cause and associated factors for neonatal deaths. In the past, nearly half of the neonatal deaths were due to immaturity, but the new classification restricted extreme prematurity to only cases below 22 weeks gestation, resulting in only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>9.3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">9.3 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">9.3%</span></span></span></span></span> of neonatal deaths</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3ec911f5.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 5.3 Causes of neonatal deaths in 2008 using the CMACE neonatal classification for England, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Crown Dependencies.
falling within this category. The major causes of neonatal deaths in the 2008 report are as follows (Fig. 5.3):</p>
<ul>
<li>respiratory disorders</li>
<li>major congenital anomalies</li>
<li>neurological disorders</li>
<li>extreme prematurity.</li>
</ul>
